title: Laws on Leprosy
shortSummary: Leviticus 13 provides detailed instructions for identifying and diagnosing various skin diseases, commonly referred to as leprosy, and the procedures priests must follow to declare a person clean or unclean. This chapter underscores the importance of holiness, purity, and the role of the priesthood in maintaining the community’s spiritual and physical health.
timeline: c. 1446 BC - The Mosaic Law given during Israel's wilderness period

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: The leader of Israel who receives God's commands and communicates them to the people.

keyCharacters.name: Aaron
keyCharacters.description: The high priest and brother of Moses, responsible for overseeing the priestly duties including diagnosing leprosy.

keyCharacters.name: Priests (sons of Aaron)
keyCharacters.description: The officiating priests who examine skin diseases and pronounce individuals clean or unclean according to the law.

definitions.definition: A term used in the Old Testament to describe various skin diseases causing ritual impurity, not necessarily the modern disease known as Hansen’s disease.
A state of ritual impurity that separates a person from the community and worship until cleansing is completed.
The practice of isolating a person suspected of having leprosy for a period of observation to determine if the disease spreads.
In this context, a visible skin disease or sore that may indicate leprosy or other impurities.

outline.heading: Initial Examination of Skin Diseases
outline.description: God instructs Moses and Aaron on how priests are to examine skin conditions resembling leprosy, including criteria for declaring a person clean or unclean and the process of isolation.

outline.heading: Diagnosis of Advanced and Widespread Leprosy
outline.description: Guidelines for identifying old leprosy and cases where the disease covers the whole body, including conditions for declaring someone clean or unclean.

outline.heading: Leprosy from Boils and Burns
outline.description: Instructions on how to distinguish between leprosy arising from healed boils or burns and other inflammations, emphasizing careful priestly examination.

outline.heading: Leprosy on the Head and Beard
outline.description: Specific rules for diagnosing leprosy on the head or beard, including signs of healing and when to isolate or pronounce clean.

outline.heading: Other Skin Conditions and Baldness
outline.description: Distinctions between harmless white spots, baldness, and leprous sores on the scalp, with instructions for priestly judgment.

outline.heading: Leprosy in Garments and Objects
outline.description: Regulations for identifying and dealing with leprous contamination in clothing and skins, including washing, isolation, and destruction if necessary.

application: Trust in God’s holiness and the importance of spiritual purity as a reflection of our relationship with Him.
Respect and obey God’s instructions for community health and holiness, recognizing the role of church leadership in spiritual oversight.
Practice patience and faith in times of trial or isolation, knowing God’s purposes include restoration and cleansing.
Maintain personal and communal holiness by avoiding sin and impurity, which separate us from God and others.

keyVerses.text: And the priest shall look on the plague in the skin of the flesh: and when the hair in the plague is turned white, and the plague in sight be deeper than the skin of his flesh, it is a plague of leprosy: and the priest shall look on him, and pronounce him unclean.
keyVerses.significance: This verse establishes the priest’s authority and the criteria for diagnosing leprosy, highlighting the seriousness of ritual impurity.

keyVerses.text: All the days wherein the plague shall be in him he shall be defiled; he is unclean: he shall dwell alone; without the camp shall his habitation be.
keyVerses.significance: It shows the social and spiritual consequences of uncleanness and the necessity of separation to protect the community.

keyVerses.text: This is the law of the plague of leprosy in a garment of woollen or linen, either in the warp, or woof, or any thing of skins, to pronounce it clean, or to pronounce it unclean.
keyVerses.significance: This concluding verse emphasizes the comprehensive nature of God’s law in addressing purity in all aspects of life, including clothing.
